snippet: With voters worn by hard times yet many of them hopeful of better times ahead, Americans tended to revert to more traditional lines as they voted on Tuesday.
abstract: Edison Research poll and millions of telephone interviews reveal an electorate that has largely reverted to the traditional ideological lines that were in place before the upheaval of 2008; Pres Obama lost the support of male white voters who had joined him in the previous elections, but held onto minorities and other traditional Democratic demographic groups.

byline.original: By JACKIE CALMES and MEGAN THEE-BRENAN

lead_paragraph: With voters worn by hard times yet many of them hopeful of better times ahead, Americans tended to revert to more traditional lines as they voted on Tuesday.

headline.main: Electorate Reverts to a Partisan Divide as Obama’s Support Narrows
headline.print_headline: Electorate Reverts to a Partisan Divide as Obama’s Support Narrows
